case_name: State of Mysore v. the respondent

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 10 of 1965 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 10 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal was by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 10, 1964 of the Mysore High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 223 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July lo, 1964 of the Mysore High Court in. Criminal Appeal No. 223 of 1963.

facts.text: H. Dhebar and S. P. Nayyar appeared for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: H. Dhebar and S.- P. Nayyar, for the appellant.

facts.text: The respondent did not appear.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent did number appear.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shelat, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shelat, J,

facts.text: Respondent is the owner of motor car bearing No. MYU-1089.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, the owner of a motor car bearing No. MYU- 1089,

facts.text: Respondent carried 8 passengers in his motor car on Nanjangud-Mysore Road on April 5, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: carried 8 passengers in his said car on Nanjangud- Mysore Road on April 5, 1963

facts.text: Respondent collected Rs. 5 from each of the 8 passengers.

anchor.surface_text: and companylected Rs. 5 from each of them.

facts.text: Respondent was charge-sheeted under section 42(1) read with section 123 of the Motor Vehicles Act 1939 for using the car as a transport vehicle without permit.

anchor.surface_text: He was charge-sheeted under section 42 1  read with section 123 of the Act for having used the said car as a transport vehicle without the permit required under section 42 1 .

facts.text: Trial Magistrate acquitted respondent without going into merits, relying on Jayaram v. The State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Magistrate did number go into the merits though the prosecution led evidence and acquitted him relying on the decision of the High Court of Mysore in Jayaram v. The State of Mysore 1 .

facts.text: State appealed to Mysore High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 223 of 1963 urging reconsideration of Jayaram decision.

anchor.surface_text: The State took the matter in appeal to the High Court urging that the said decision required reconsideration. On the view that it did number, , the High Court dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Mysore High Court dismissed the State's appeal.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the acquittal by trial Magistrate and High Court, and directed Magistrate to proceed on merits.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, therefore, allowed. The order of acquittal passed by the trial Magistrate and companyfirmed by the High Court is set aside and the Magistrate is directed to proceed with the case on merits in accordance with law and in the light of the observations made in this judgment.

facts.text: In B.S. Usman Saheb v. State of Mysore, owner carried cement bags and goods without permit under s.42(1).

anchor.surface_text: In B.S. Usman Saheb v. The State of Mysore 2  the question arose whether an owner of a motor car who had carried cement bags and other goods from one place to another without a permit under section 42 1

facts.text: In Usman Saheb case, trial Magistrate convicted accused holding vehicle converted to goods vehicle requiring permit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Magistrate companyvicted the accused on the ground that once the car was used to transport goods, the vehicle was companyverted into a goods vehicle and required permit.

facts.text: In Usman Saheb case, Mysore High Court set aside conviction holding mere use for goods does not convert to goods vehicle.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court set aside the companyviction holding that the mere fact that the owner of such motor vehicle used it for transporting goods did number mean that the vehicle was companyverted into a goods vehicle so as to attract section 42 1 .

facts.text: In Jayaram v. State of Mysore, accused used registered motor car for carrying passengers for reward.

anchor.surface_text: Likewise in Jayaram v. The State of Mysore 1  the accused who had his motor vehicle registered as a motor car used it for ,carrying passengers, for reward.

facts.text: In Jayaram case, Mysore High Court held registered motor car is not transport vehicle, no prosecution under s.42(1).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the ,said vehicle having been registered as a motor car as defined by section 2 16  was number a transport vehicle and numberprosecution companyld lie under section 42 1 .

facts.text: State of Mysore challenges correctness of Usman Saheb and Jayaram decisions.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Mysore challenges the companyrectness of these decisions companytending that though a motor vehicle is registered as a motor car, if it is used for a purpose set out in section 42 1

facts.text: Trial Magistrate did not go into merits though prosecution led evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Magistrate did number go into the merits though the prosecution led evidence

issues.text: the question as to the true meaning of section 42(1) of the Motor Vehicles Act, 4 of 1939

anchor.surface_text: raises the question as to the true meaning of section 42 1  of the Motor Vehicles Act  4 of 1939 .

issues.text: whether, though a motor vehicle is registered as a motor car, if it is used for carrying passengers for hire or reward without a permit, there is a breach of section 42(1)

anchor.surface_text: The State of Mysore challenges the correctness of these decisions contending that though a motor vehicle is registered as a motor car, if it is used for a purpose set out in section 42 1  viz., carrying passengers for hire or reward, the motor vehicle on that occasion must be said to have been used as a transport vehicle, and if so used without a permit, there would be a breach of that provision and the owner so using it or permitting it to be so used would be liable to be convicted.

issues.text: whether section 42(1) applies only to motor vehicles registered as transport vehicles or also to those used as transport vehicles

anchor.surface_text: Section 42 1  no doubt uses the words owner of a transport vehicle and provides that he shall no use or permit its use in any public place save in accordance with the conditions of a permit granted or countersigned by the prescribed authority. These words, however, cannot mean that the sub-section applies only to cases where the motor vehicle in question is registered as a transport vehicle. If that were so, a person can use his motor vehicle,provided it is no a transport vehicle, for carrying passengers for hire or reward without having to take out a permit for its use as a transport vehicle.

arguments.claim: Acquittal because no merits consideration needed, relying on Jayaram precedent where registered motor car is not a transport vehicle.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Magistrate did number go into the merits though the prosecution led evidence and acquitted him relying on the decision of the High Court of Mysore in Jayaram v. The State of Mysore 1 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e appeal is, therefore, allowed. The order of acquittal passed by the trial Magistrate and companyfirmed by the High Court is set aside and the Magist

arguments.court_reasoning: Mysore High Court view incorrect; s.42(1) applies based on use as transport vehicle.

arguments.claim: Jayaram decision does not require reconsideration; affirm acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The State took the matter in appeal to the High Court urging that the said decision required reconsideration. On the view that it did number, , the High Court dismissed the appeal.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e appeal is, therefore, allowed. The order of acquittal passed by the trial Magistrate and companyfirmed by the High Court is set aside and the Magist

arguments.court_reasoning: View taken by Mysore High Court incorrect.

arguments.claim: In Jayaram, registered motor car as per s.2(16) is not a transport vehicle; no prosecution under s.42(1).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the ,said vehicle having been registered as a motor car as defined by section 2 16  was number a transport vehicle and numberprosecution companyld lie under section 42 1 .

arguments.court_reasoning: View taken by the Mysore High Court with respect is number correct.

arguments.claim: In Usman Saheb, mere use of motor car for transporting goods does not convert it into a goods vehicle attracting s.42(1).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court set aside the conviction holding that the mere fact that the owner of such motor vehicle used it for transporting goods did number mean that the vehicle was converted into a goods vehicle so as to attract section 42 1 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ject of s. 42 i . The appeal is, therefo

arguments.court_reasoning: Challenges correctness; use determines category under definitions.

arguments.claim: Though registered as motor car, use for carrying passengers for hire or reward makes it a transport vehicle; breach of s.42(1) without permit.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Mysore challenges the correctness of these decisions contending that though a motor vehicle is registered as a motor car, if it is used for a purpose set out in section 42 1  viz., carrying passengers for hire or reward, the motor vehicle on that occasion must be said to have been used as a transport vehicle, and if so used without a permit, there would be a breach of that provision and the owner so using it or permitting it to be so used would be liable to be convicted.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ovides that he shall number use or permit its use in any public place save in accordance with the companyditions of a permit granted or companyntersig

arguments.court_reasoning: Purposive construction effectuates control object; definitions support use-based classification.

arguments.claim: s.42(1) 'owner of a transport vehicle' cannot mean only registered transport vehicles; else anomaly of using any non-transport vehicle for hire without permit.

anchor.surface_text: Section 42 1 numberdoubt uses the words owner of a transport vehicle and provides that he shall number use or permit its use in any public place save in accordance with the conditions of a permit granted or countersigned by the prescribed authority. These words, however, cannot mean that the sub-section applies only to cases where the motor vehicle in question is registered as a transport vehicle.

arguments.claim: s.42(1) must be construed to effectuate legislative object of controlling transport vehicles.

anchor.surface_text: The sub-section, therefore, must be construed in such a manner as to effectuate the object for which it was enacted. So construed, it must mean that if a person owns. a motor vehicle and uses it or permits its use as a transport vehicle he can do so provided he takes out the requisite permit therefor

arguments.claim: Use as public service vehicle (carrying passengers for hire/reward) makes any motor vehicle a transport vehicle per definitions in s.2(25), s.2(33).

anchor.surface_text: What the sub- section emphasises is the use of a motor vehicle as a transport vehicle and the necessity of a Permit which is required for purposes of exercising control over vehicles used as transport vehicles. This is clear from the definitions of transport vehicle and a public service vehicle.

arguments.claim: Mysore High Court construction defeats object of s.42(1) for passenger safety control.

anchor.surface_text: The construction accepted by the High Court of Mysore were correct, it would mean that whereas an owner of a transport vehicle is required to have the permit, the owner of a motor vehicle not constructed or adapted as a transport vehicle can carry with impunity passengers for hire or reward without any permit therefor. Section 42 1  has been enacted for the purpose of controlling vehicles carrying passengers, the object of such control being obviously to ensure safety of passengers.

arguments.claim: Similar to Payne v. Allcock: use/purpose determines classification and duty/permit requirement, regardless of construction/adaptation.

anchor.surface_text: A similar construction was given to para 5 d  of Sch. 11 of the Finance Act, 1920 and section 14 of the Finance Act, 1922 in Payne v. Allcock.  1  Section 14 of the Finance Act, 1922 provided that where a licence was taken out for a mechanically-propelled vehicle at any rate under the Second Schedule of the Finance Act, 1920 and the vehicle was at any time, while such a licence was in force, used in an altered condition or in a manner or for a purpose which brings it within,

arguments.claim: As in Public Prosecutor v. Captain R. Rajagopalan and Re. Manager, Indian Express: even occasional/single use for hire/reward/goods makes vehicle subject to permit rules.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly in Public Prosecutor v. Captain R. Rajagopalan 1  the High Court of Madras held that though rule 30 a  of the Madras Motor Vehicles Rules was intended to apply to motor vehicles used for the express purpose of letting for hire, if a motor vehicle was used even once for such a purpose, then, on that one occasion it was nonetheless let for hire.

arguments.claim: Combined effect of s.42(1) and definitions requires permit for any motor vehicle used as transport vehicle.

anchor.surface_text: The combined effect of S. 42 1  and the definitions of a motor vehicle, a public service vehicle and a transport vehicle is that if a motor vehicle is used as a transport vehicle, the owner who so uses it or permits it to be so used is required to obtain the necessary permit.

holdings.text: Section 42(1) cannot mean that the sub-section applies only to cases where the motor vehicle in question is registered as a transport vehicle.

anchor.surface_text: Section 42 1  numberdoubt uses the words owner of a transport vehicle and provides that he shall number use or permit its use in any public place save in accordance with the companyditions of a permit granted or companyntersigned by the prescribed authority. These words, however, cannot mean that the sub-section applies only to cases where the motor vehicle in question is registered as a transport vehicle. If that were so, a person can use his motor vehicle,provided it is number a transport vehicle, for carrying passengers for hire or reward without having to take out a permit for its use asa transport vehicle.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal reading leads to anomalous result allowing unregulated hire use; purposive construction required for legislative control object.

holdings.text: The sub-section must be construed to mean that if a person owns a motor vehicle and uses it or permits its use as a transport vehicle he can do so provided he takes out the requisite permit therefor.

anchor.surface_text: The sub-section, therefore, must be companystrued in such a manner as to effectuate the object for which it was enacted. So companystrued, it must mean that if a person owns. a motor vehicle and uses it or permits its use as a transport vehicle he can do so provided he takes out the requisite permit therefor If he does number take out the permit and uses it or permits its use Ls a transport vehicle he companymits an infringement of the- subsection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Effectuate object of control over transport vehicles via permit requirement based on use.

holdings.text: Any motor vehicle used for carriage of passengers for hire or reward is regarded when so used as a public service vehicle and therefore a transport vehicle; such use without permit breaches s.42(1).

anchor.surface_text: What the sub- section emphasises is the use of a motor vehicle as a transport vehicle and the necessity of a Permit which is reqred for purposes of exercising companytrol over vehicles used as transport vehicles. This is clear from the definitions of transport vehicle and a public service vehicle. A transport vehicle means a public service vehicle and a public service vehicle means any motor vehicle either used or adapted to be used for carriage of passengers for hire or reward. Therefore, any motor vehicle used for carriage of passengers for hire or reward is regarded when so used as a public service vehicle and therefore a transport vehicle.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definitions in s.2(25),(33) make classification use-based; harmonious reading with s.42(1).

holdings.text: Even if a motor vehicle is occasionally used for carrying passengers for hire or reward it must be regarded when so used as a public service vehicle and therefore a transport vehicle and if it is so used without the necessary permit such use would be in breach of s. 42(1) and the owner would be liable to be punished under s.42(1) read with s.123.

anchor.surface_text: it is the use of the motor vehicle for carrying passengers for hire or reward which determines the category of the motor vehicle whether it is adapted for that purpose or number. It must follow that even if a motor vehicle is occasionally used for carrying passengers for hire or reward it must be regarded when so used as a public service vehicle and therefore a transport vehicle and if it is so used without the necessary permit such use would be in breach of s. 42 1  and the owner who uses it or permits it to be so used would be liable to be punished under S. 42 1  read with S. 123.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Use, even occasional, triggers definitions and permit obligation; supported by English and Indian precedents.

holdings.text: The combined effect of s.42(1) and the definitions of a motor vehicle, a public service vehicle and a transport vehicle is that if a motor vehicle is used as a transport vehicle, the owner who so uses it or permits it to be so used is required to obtain the necessary permit.

anchor.surface_text: The companybined effect of S. 42 1  and the definitions of a motor vehicle, a public service vehicle and a transport vehicle is that if a motor vehicle is used as a transport vehicle, the owner who so uses it or permits it to be so used is required to obtain the necessary permit. It is the use of the motor vehicle for carrying passengers for hire or reward which determines the application of s. 42 1 .

holdings.text: The view taken by the Mysore High Court with respect is not correct.

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the Mysore High Court with respect is number companyrect and the view taken by the High Court of Madras is number only companyrect but is in companysonance with the purpose and object of s. 42 i .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contradicts purposive interpretation and object of passenger safety control.

anchor.surface_text: Section 42 1  numberdoubt uses the words owner of a transport vehicle and provides that he shall number use or permit its use in any public place save in accordance with the companyditions of a permit granted or companyntersigned by the prescribed authority. These words, however, cannot mean that the sub-section applies only to cases where the motor vehicle in question is registered as a transport vehicle. If that were so, a person can use his motor vehicle,provided it is number a transport vehicle, for carrying passengers for hire or reward without having to take out a permit for its use asa transport vehicle.

The appeal is, therefore, allowed. The order of acquittal passed by the trial Magistrate and companyfirmed by the High Court is set aside and the Magistrate is directed to proceed with the case on merits in accordance with law and in the light of the observations made in this judgment.

The sub-section, therefore, must be companystrued in such a manner as to effectuate the object for which it was enacted. So companystrued, it must mean that if a person owns. a motor vehicle and uses it or permits its use as a transport vehicle he can do so provided he takes out the requisite permit therefor If he does number take out the permit and uses it or permits its use Ls a transport vehicle he companymits an infringement of the- subsection.

The appeal is, therefore, allowed. The order of acquittal passed by the trial Magistrate and companyfirmed by the High Court is set aside and the Magistrate is directed to proceed with the case on merits in accordance with law and in the light of the observations made in this judgment.

anchor.surface_text: What the sub- section emphasises is the use of a motor vehicle as a transport vehicle and the necessity of a Permit which is reqred for purposes of exercising companytrol over vehicles used as transport vehicles. This is clear from the definitions of transport vehicle and a public service vehicle. A transport vehicle means a public service vehicle and a public service vehicle means any motor vehicle either used or adapted to be used for carriage of passengers for hire or reward. Therefore, any motor vehicle used for carriage of passengers for hire or reward is regarded when so used as a public service vehicle and therefore a transport vehicle.

anchor.surface_text: it is the use of the motor vehicle for carrying passengers for hire or reward which determines the category of the motor vehicle whether it is adapted for that purpose or number. It must follow that even if a motor vehicle is occasionally used for carrying passengers for hire or reward it must be regarded when so used as a public service vehicle and therefore a transport vehicle and if it is so used without the necessary permit such use would be in breach of s. 42 1  and the owner who uses it or permits it to be so used would be liable to be punished under S. 42 1  read with S. 123.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, therefore, allowed. The order of acquittal passed by the trial Magistrate and companyfirmed by the High Court is set aside and the Magistrate is directed to proceed with the case on merits in accordance with law and in the light of the observations made in this judgment.

The companybined effect of S. 42 1  and the definitions of a motor vehicle, a public service vehicle and a transport vehicle is that if a motor vehicle is used as a transport vehicle, the owner who so uses it or permits it to be so used is required to obtain the necessary permit. It is the use of the motor vehicle for carrying passengers for hire or reward which determines the application of s. 42 1 .

The appeal is, therefore, allowed. The order of acquittal passed by the trial Magistrate and companyfirmed by the High Court is set aside and the Magistrate is directed to proceed with the case on merits in accordance with law and in the light of the observations made in this judgment.
